        The Gallipoli War, also known as the Battle of Gallipoli or the Gallipoli Campaign, took place on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey during World War I, from February 1915 to January 1916. The campaign was a significant part of the First World War, involving the Entente powers (Britain, France, and the Russian Empire) seeking to weaken the Ottoman Empire, one of the Central Powers, by gaining control of the straits that provided a supply route to Russia. The Allies' attack on Ottoman forts at the entrance of the Dardanelles in February 1915 failed, leading to an amphibious landing on the Gallipoli peninsula in April 1915 in an attempt to capture the Ottoman capital of Constantinople (Istanbul).

The Gallipoli Peninsula Historical National Park is known for the battles fought during the First World War, with various remnants still present at the park, including building structures and sunken ships. The area holds significance for Turkish, Australian, and New Zealand cultures due to the large number of soldiers from these countries who fought and died during the war.

The Gallipoli campaign was a devastating battle involving multiple countries, including Australia, and commemorative services are held at Anzac Cove at Gallipoli, with the cooperation and assistance of the Government of the Republic of Turkey.

The role of Gallipoli in the Greco-Turkish War of 1919–22 and its occupation by Greek and British troops after World War I are also mentioned in the passages.

Overall, the Gallipoli War took place in a strategically important location and had far-reaching implications for the countries involved, making it a significant event in the history of World War I.

The Allies' attack on Ottoman forts at the entrance of the Dardanelles in February 1915 failed and was followed by an amphibious landing on the Gallipoli peninsula in April 1915 to capture the Ottoman capital of Constantinople (Istanbul).

The park contains various remnants such as building structures and sunken ships, and memorials remember soldiers from Turkey, England, France, Australia, and New Zealand. The significance of the Gallipoli Campaign in Turkish, Australian, and New Zealand cultures is due to the large percentage of each country’s population who fought or died during the war.
